text: Surely this is already priced in?

attachments.fallback: [April 11th, 2020 10:30 PM] demhadbale: Not trying to call the bottom but if you feel things will drop why would you buy? My view is the economy is going to tank so I'm not getting involved in any stocks that will be affected by high unemployment and significant drops in income. Next quarter a lot of companies will be showing pretty bad fundamentals. This is much worse than 2008. I'm not a trader either and by horizon is about 30 years. If you're 10-20% off at the beginning, compounding that over years is going to make a massive difference. I dont care what the highs are and the current prices relative to them. Would you call a horse value just because it traded at 25% lower than it's current odds?
attachments.text: Not trying to call the bottom but if you feel things will drop why would you buy? Would you call a horse value just because it traded at 25% lower than it's current odds?

elements.text: Surely this is already priced in?

text: That requires a high degree of confidence in the emh and I think history shows that the market often gets things very wrong. I don't even know what "priced in" even means. If everything was priced in then wouldn't stock prices be infinite because in the long run growth always happens? Further, how do you price in something with this degree of uncertainty? What happens is ultimately based on how the whole world reacts and this is unpredictable. Were things "priced in" directly after the mortgage crisis? No, it was a bear market for several months. This time around there was a massive sell off weeks ago when the situation was very different and there was a lot less information and the market has been rebounding ever since, despite worsening news (bad polcies, high unemployment, further lockdowns). Seemingly because of stimulus band-aids which may, with the consequence of inflation, hold over for now, but what about next month? and the month after that? Dont think the market had all relevant information at that point or could accurately price things right now. It's hard enough to price things in normal times and we are not in normal times. Time will tell I guess.

text: Also, if everything were accurately priced in, then there would be no benefit to investing in individual stocks. It would make more sense to invest in an index fund since under emh you can't between the market. Which while true for many funds, is not for all of them. See Soros, Dalio, Simons, Buffet. <https://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/articles/columbia-business/superinvestors>

attachments.title: The Superinvestors of Graham-and-Doddsville
attachments.text: “Superinvestor” Warren E. Buffett, who got an A+ from Ben Graham at Columbia in 1951, never stopped making the grade. He made his fortune using the principles of Graham and Dodd's Security Analysis. Here, in celebration of the 50th anniversary of that classic text, he tracks the records of investors who stick to the “value approach” and have gotten rich going by the book.
attachments.fallback: Ideas & Insights: The Superinvestors of Graham-and-Doddsville

text: I'm not sure it does require belief in EMH and I certainly don't think it's true. I just think we've reached something of a steady state here where it's clear that coronavirus is going to have a massive negative impact on the world economy.

text: Yes we have, but to what extent is not obvious. It's possible that the market is optimistic or miscalculated. It's not a perfect mechanism. When I look at 2008 and place myself a couple of weeks after the big news hit it was a very similar situation. It was obvious that it was going to be bad and had everything been priced in, the market wouldn't continue to be bearish for next few quarters. It seems that what we're in now is worse than 2008, if you judge by the stimulus packages alone. Even if we crippled the virus today, there could very likely be another surge. We might be in this for years even if someone comes up with a vaccine today.

elements.text: Yes we have, but to what extent is not obvious. It's possible that the market is optimistic or miscalculated. It's not a perfect mechanism. It seems that what we're in now is worse than 2008, if you judge by the stimulus packages alone. Even if we crippled the virus today, there could very likely be another surge. We might be in this for years even if someone comes up with a vaccine today.

text: I think if you try and chase the lows you’ll probably miss them. Regular investments will get the highs and lows and most likely average out at a decent price over time.

elements.text: I think if you try and chase the lows you’ll probably miss them. Regular investments will get the highs and lows and most likely average out at a decent price over time.

text: That's fair and in normal times I'd agree, but I would be very cautious right now. Traditional wisdom goes out the window during unusual times. There's no rush to get in, things aren't going to improve anytime soon and there will still be opportunities even if things dont spiral downward. But if they do spiral we're looking at more staggering drops. So in the coming months the potential downside is greater than the upside, so I can stand to wait and see how things pan out. For me the important thing is to avoid inflation, and I think the best way to do that would be to invest in certain commodities.

elements.text: That's fair and in normal times I'd agree, but I would be very cautious right now. Traditional wisdom goes out the window during unusual times. There's no rush to get in, things aren't going to improve anytime soon and there will still be opportunities even if things dont spiral downward. But if they do spiral we're looking at more staggering drops. So in the coming months the potential downside is greater than the upside, so I can stand to wait and see how things pan out. For me the important thing is to avoid inflation, and I think the best way to do that would be to invest in certain commodities.

text: I don’t plan on changing what I do, dollar cost averaging mixed with diversifying, there is more than just stocks out there

text: The whole "priced in" concept is _always_ relative to some horizon btw - should make it easier to understand why stock prices wouldn't be "infinite" cus of growth in the long term. The puzzle is to 1. figure out what your investment horizon is and 2. analyse whether there is value in current prices with regards to that specific horizon (referring to message at 09:00)

text: Given all the uncertainty it's likely there a large number stocks both massively over valued and undervalued on various horizons, unlike during periods of more certainty when investors are better able to value securities.

text:
<@U4H19D1D2> “dollar cost averaging mixed with diversifying”
100% agree. Any idea of being able to predict the short term due to the number of variables that contribute to the price moving is to risky, in my opinion, to be attempted with any size that would equate to meaningful gains. I am not an expert by any means, but i think doing so, proficiently, is a full time job. I am looking at long term / large cap / dividend etc. Keeping a smaller position in more risky pursuit  .. like betfairlightweight ..

text:
I consider bflw lower risk than the stockmarket.

Suppose you make £xx,xxx from bflw. The chances are that you won't be able to reinvest that money in Betfair. So you will withdraw it and have less money at risk (hence my initial question). However, stocks probably have a higher chance of silly exponential growth than bflw. Bflw is more like a job with (relative to the stock market) steady returns.
